albsavoia wrote:
> J.B. Writes:
> 
>  > Also, Agitator can help retrofit tests to legacy code, however it
>  > /doesn't/ help you identify the specific design problems in that code,
>  > nor does it motivate you to improve the design. This might or might not
>  > concern your team at this time.
> 
> This is Alberto jumping in again to set the record straight on
> Agitator ...
> 
> Hi Joe, you might not remember me but we exchanged emails a couple of
> years ago, and I am a big fan of yours for all the work you have done
> to educate people about JUnit through your book and online presence.
> 
> Anyway ... your description of using Agitator to complement TDD is
> spot-on (for people who do TDD) - thank you for jumping in and helping
> in setting the record straight.  But you also state (I paraphrase):
> "Agitator does not help you identify design problems or motivate you
> to improve the design".  We have actually found, somewhat
> serendipitously, that Agitator does indeed help you in identifying
> design problems and even provides you compelling motivations to
> address them (e.g. well designed code Agitates better).
> 
> A simple example, of Agitator helping you improve your design is
> blogged on developertesting.com:
> 
> http://www.developertesting.com/archives/month200402/20040226-TestDrivenDevelopmentAndAgitatorDrivenRefactoring.html
> 
> Again, this does not mean that Agitator replaces TDD, but it can
> complement TDD efforts (our own Dashboard product was developed
> practicing TDD, pair-programming, etc., AND Agitator of course).

This is an interesting article, Alberto, and I thank you for involving 
yourself in this thread. It's great to have you here.

Now I don't necessarily agree that checking an exception message is 
/good design/. I also don't necessarily agree that having a negative 
value for 'score' is cause for an exception--it depends where the system 
boundaries are.

Even with all that, it is clear that Agitator did help Jeffrey follow 
his coding style, and that is quite good.

Finally, I should mention that this is not the kind of design problem I 
have in mind when I made my admittedly baseless claim. Since it was 
baseless, I should revise my claim. Here it is:

     When I write JUnit tests, I am forced to deal with dependency
     problems in my code. I don't yet have any evidence that Agitator
     would help me with that. I am concerned that since Agitator helps
     me /not/ write JUnit tests, it might also help me /not/ feel the
     pain of those kinds of dependency problems.

Thanks for helping me clarify things, Alberto. I don't like 
misrepresenting someone else's product.

Take care.
